title: HIGH: Certificate serial numbers use predictable timestamps
close_reason: Already fixed. internal/tls/ca.go:117-120 uses generateRandomSerial() for cryptographically random serial numbers.

close_reason: Fixed in Phase 2.2.5 - Gemini pattern

title: LOW: Express 5.x is still relatively new - may have undiscovered vulnerabilities
close_reason: N/A - Langley is Go-based, not Node/Express

title: HIGH: Unix socket created with world-readable permissions (0666)
close_reason: False positive. No Unix socket in codebase - all listeners use TCP (main.go:190, mitm.go:136, proxy.go:84).

title: 2.4.5: FTS5 full-text search on bodies
description:
Research spike to find right setup.

Goal: Search captured request/response bodies.

Questions to answer:
- Does modernc/sqlite include FTS5? (PoC required per PHASE2.md)
- If not, fallback to LIKE queries acceptable?
- Index redacted bodies only (security)
- How to handle redaction pattern changes on existing data?
- Search UI/UX in dashboard?

From PHASE2.md:
```go
// Verify FTS5 support
_, err := db.Exec(`CREATE VIRTUAL TABLE test_fts USING fts5(content)`)
```

Acceptance: PoC confirms FTS5 works or documents fallback.
notes: PoC COMPLETE: FTS5 confirmed working with modernc/sqlite. TestFTS5Support passes. Next: Add flows_fts table, /api/flows/search endpoint, search UI.

title: LOW: HTTP/1.1 server timeouts disabled (timeout=0) creates connection exhaustion risk
close_reason: By design. Read/Write timeouts disabled for SSE streaming (LLM responses can take minutes). IdleTimeout=120s handles orphaned connections. Comment in proxy.go:73 explains rationale.

title: LOW: Langley design lacks input validation specs for config file parsing
close_reason: Not needed. Config uses strict YAML parsing with typed structs (internal/config/config.go). Invalid fields cause parse errors. Default values are safe.

title: HIGH: Request body fully buffered before proxy - memory exhaustion with large uploads
close_reason: Mitigated. Body buffering is limited by BodyMaxBytes (default 1MB) via io.LimitReader in mitm.go:177,405. Memory exhaustion prevented by size cap.

title: REDACTION: Body redaction regex runs on full body - ReDoS possible with crafted input
close_reason: Fixed in Phase 2.2.12 - 1MB input limit

title: AUTH: Auth token logged in debug output (api.go:80) - redact before logging
close_reason: Fixed in Phase 2.2.6 - logs only length

title: AUTH: Token passed in URL query param (token=) is logged and may leak in server logs
close_reason: Fixed in Phase 2.2.7 - returns 400

title: AUTH: Bearer token comparison vulnerable to timing attack - use constant-time compare
close_reason: Fixed in Phase 2.2.10 - subtle.ConstantTimeCompare

title: DATA EXPOSURE: SQLite database file has no explicit permissions set - inherits parent dir
close_reason: Fixed in Phase 2.2.11 - 0600 permissions on Unix

title: CRITICAL: No credential redaction in Clancy reference - API keys stored in plaintext
close_reason: N/A - Clancy is a reference project, not part of Langley

title: INPUT: SSE parser has no max buffer size - malicious response can cause OOM (addresses Phase 1.5.2)
close_reason: Fixed in Phase 1.5.2 - SSE parser limits

title: MEDIUM: SQLite WAL without proper locking may corrupt under concurrent access
close_reason: Not an issue. SQLite properly configured: WAL mode, SetMaxOpenConns(1) for single-writer pattern, busy_timeout=5000ms. This is correct SQLite concurrency handling.

title: LOW: Langley design host binding to localhost provides no guarantee against port forwarding
close_reason: Acceptable. Localhost binding + auth token + rate limiting provides defense in depth. Port forwarding is user-initiated action outside tool's threat model.

title: LOW: refraction-networking/utls is a third-party fork of Go crypto/tls
close_reason: Acceptable risk. utls is widely used for TLS fingerprinting. The proxy uses it for JA3/JA4 detection, not security-critical operations.

title: MEDIUM: CA certificate 10-year validity is excessive
close_reason: Already fixed. internal/tls/ca.go:22 shows CAValidityYears reduced from 10 to 2 years.

title: HIGH: In-memory certificate cache never evicts - memory exhaustion possible
close_reason: Already fixed. internal/tls/certcache.go implements LRU cache with evictOldest() and configurable maxSize (default 1000).

title: REDACTION GAP: JSON-escaped keys not handled - \"x-api-key\" bypasses header redaction
close_reason: Fixed in Phase 2.2 P0 - JSON-escaped key redaction

title: 1.5: Race detection verification
description:
Verification gap identified by Reba.

Issue: Phase 1.5 acceptance requires 'go test -race ./...' to pass, but this requires CGO which is unavailable on Windows dev environment.

Options:
1. Document Linux/macOS CI run where race detection passed
2. Run manually on non-Windows environment
3. Set up GitHub Actions with race detection
4. Mark as known limitation

Acceptance: Either race detection passes on some verified environment, or gap is documented as known limitation.

title: MEDIUM: WebSocket messages broadcast to all clients without flow-level isolation
close_reason: By design. Local dev tool dashboard broadcasts to all connected clients intentionally - single user typically viewing all proxy traffic. Flow-level isolation not needed.

title: MEDIUM: RSA 2048-bit keys may be considered weak for long-lived CA certificates
close_reason: Acceptable for use case. RSA-2048 is NIST-approved until 2030. CA cert validity is only 2 years. For local dev proxy, this key strength is appropriate.

title: MEDIUM: Langley redaction patterns may miss embedded credentials in JSON values
close_reason: Fixed in Phase 2.2.13 - JSON credential field redaction

title: 2.4.7: Keyboard shortcuts (j/k, / search)
description:
Needs research.

Goal: Vim-style navigation and quick search access.

Research needed:
- j/k for list navigation (flows, tasks, etc.)
- / to focus search
- Escape to clear/close
- ? for help overlay?

- Accessibility considerations?

Acceptance: Research complete, approach documented.

title: MEDIUM: Clancy flow storage has no eviction - unbounded memory growth
close_reason: False positive. No 'Clancy' code exists in codebase - likely refers to removed/nonexistent component.

title: MEDIUM: Error messages may leak internal paths and stack traces
close_reason: Not an issue. Error messages use %w wrapping with generic context (e.g., 'listen: %w', 'config is required'). No stack traces or internal paths exposed.

title: HIGH: Langley design specifies raw body storage flag default OFF but no enforcement mechanism
close_reason: Fixed. Added ShouldStoreRawBody() check in mitm.go before storing request/response bodies. When RawBodyStorage=false (default), bodies are not stored. Test added: TestMITMProxy_RawBodyStorageOff

title: LOW: Node-forge dependency is a known audit target for cryptographic implementations
close_reason: N/A - Langley is Go-based, not Node/Node-forge

title: MEDIUM: Console logging may persist sensitive data to log files
close_reason: Not an issue. Logging is secure: auth failures log token LENGTH not value (api.go:126), config reload logs whether token changed as boolean (api.go:713). No sensitive data logged.

title: 2.4.4: Export flows as CSV/JSON
description:
Research spike to find right setup.

Goal: Allow users to download captured flows for external analysis.

Questions to answer:
- What fields to include in export?
- Streaming export for large datasets vs in-memory?
- Frontend download trigger vs API endpoint?
- Date range / filter support?
- How to handle large response bodies?

Acceptance: Document approach, define API contract.
close_reason: Spike complete. Documented in .docs/spikes/export-flows.md. Key decisions: NDJSON streaming for large exports, summary (default) vs full (with bodies) modes, API endpoint at GET /api/flows/export with existing filters + format/include_bodies params. ~300 LOC to implement.

title: CORS: localhost origin check doesn't validate port - localhost:9999 allowed
close_reason: By design. All localhost origins trusted since this is a local dev tool. Port doesn't matter - any localhost app is presumed trusted.
